title: Official Blind Review #3
review_assessment:_thoroughness_in_paper: I read the paper at least twice and used my best judgement in assessing the paper.
review:
This paper solves the problem of unsupervised domain adaptive object detection. They proposed a method on top of Strong-Weak alignment (Saito et al., 2019). In this previous work, two losses are proposed, a weak-alignment loss for global features and strong-alignment loss for local features. In addition, the previous work proposed to utilize context-vector for effective object detection. 

Their contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.
1, adversarial alignment losses for low-level features by adding domain classifier to many low-level layers
2, adding context features from the low-level features 
3, they proposed to detach the gradient from the context features to avoid a negative transfer.  
4, the effectiveness of their method is validated through extensive experiments on many object detection datasets. 

I lean toward rejecting this paper from the following weakness.

1, Their method lacks technical novelty to accept. Adding many domain classifiers to lower-level layers and adding more context vectors are just minor modifications to Strong-Weak alignment (Saito et al., 2019). In Strong-Weak alignment (Saito et al., 2019), the idea of performing adaptation in multiple-layers and using context-vector are proposed. In Chen et al., 2018, using instance-level features for alignment is proposed. Although the use of these techniques is a slightly different from these existing works,  the difference is too minor. 
2, The presentation is poor, especially in the introduction. For example, they introduced COL in the introduction. However, I could not see a close connection with this paper. In "Our key ideas" part, it is also unclear what was the key idea and novel idea.
